docs.title: 📚 OSINT Toolkit Documentation – Table of Contents
docs.text: This repository contains improved and fully detailed Markdown documentation for OSINT operations, tools, and environments. Each document is designed for professionals with a technical background, such as computer science graduates or infosec practitioners entering the OSINT field.

docs.title: 🖥️ 1. kali virtualbox set up
docs.text:
Description: Step-by-step instructions to install Kali Linux inside VirtualBox, configure the system for OSINT work, optimize browser hygiene, set up VPN, and take snapshots for reproducible environments.

Key Sections: - Install VirtualBox and Kali Linux - Post-install setup and tool automation - Installing Guest Additions - Browser configuration for OSINT - Installing and configuring NordVPN - Snapshot and clean profile best practices

docs.title: 💽 2. resize-your-VM
docs.text:
Description: Complete guide to expanding the virtual hard disk size of a Kali Linux VM and resizing partitions within the guest system using GParted.

Key Sections: - Resize .vdi file using VBoxManage on Windows - Install and use GParted inside Kali - Confirming expanded disk space

docs.title: 🔍 3. Google-Dork
docs.text:
Description: Comprehensive tutorial and cheat sheet on Google Dorking, including operator syntax, filters, and OSINT-specific search tricks for identifying public information across the web.

Key Sections: - Face-only image search tricks - Google Dork operator examples (site:, filetype:, intitle:, etc.) - Search templates for documents, backups, exposed directories - Wildcarding and combining filters for precise queries

docs.title: 🆚 4. Tails-VS-Kali
docs.text:
Description: Comparative guide analyzing the use cases, pros, and cons of Tails vs. Kali Linux for OSINT tasks, along with operational security recommendations.

Key Sections: - Tails: anonymity-first investigations - Kali: tool-rich investigations - Threat modeling and OpSec best practices - General legal/ethical guidance

docs.title: 🛰️ 5. theHarvester
docs.text:
Description: In-depth reference manual for using theHarvester for passive reconnaissance. Includes advanced command syntax, use cases, and integration with custom wordlists and external APIs.

Key Sections: - Basic usage and help commands - 30+ annotated command templates - Screenshot capture, output formats, DNS options - Wordlist management and batch scanning tips

docs.title: 🧰6. Free OSINT Tools List
docs.text:
Description: A curated directory of completely free and open-source OSINT tools across multiple domains—general reconnaissance, subdomain discovery, phone/email tracking, image metadata, dark web crawling, and username verification. Ideal for analysts, penetration testers, and threat hunters operating without commercial tools.

Key Sections: - Categorized tool list: General, Specific, Social Media, Metadata - GitHub and official site links for each tool - Focused only on tools with no paid tiers or usage restrictions - Ideal for offline labs, workshops, and training setups - Includes tools like Amass, IntelOwl, ExifTool, OnionScan, and more

docs.title: 🔧 General OSINT Tools (Free)
docs.text: Tool Purpose / Use Link OSINT Framework Curated directory of OSINT tools Visit MISP Threat intelligence platform GitHub DataSploit Automates OSINT gathering and visualization GitHub OnionScan Scans/analyzes Dark Web .onion services GitHub

docs.title: 🔍 Specific Investigation Tools (Free)
docs.text: Tool Purpose / Use Link theHarvester Gathers emails, subdomains, IPs GitHub Metagoofil Extracts metadata from public docs GitHub Infoga Email-related data from public sources GitHub PhoneInfoga Gathers phone-number OSINT GitHub PwnedOrNot Checks email against data breaches Uses HaveIBeenPwned API Creepy Maps geolocation from media/social sources GitHub Recon-ng Web reconnaissance framework GitHub TorBot Crawls Dark Web .onion domains GitHub Skype-OSINT Gathers Skype profile data Various scripts available online Gasmask Automates subdomain reconnaissance GitHub Amass Attack surface discovery & network mapping GitHub Subfinder Passive subdomain enumeration GitHub IntelOwl Threat intelligence aggregation GitHub Sublist3r Subdomain enumeration using search engines GitHub Email2Phonenumber Obtains phone via email reset flows GitHub InSpy LinkedIn enumeration tool GitHub ExifTool Reads/writes metadata in images/audio/video Website, GitHub

docs.title: 🌐 Social Media & Username Tools (Free)
docs.text: Tool Purpose / Use Link CheckUsernames Checks username availability across sites GitHub SpinXO Username generator/checker Visit

docs.title: 🕵️ OSINT Environment Selection: Kali Linux vs Tails OS
docs.text: When performing Open Source Intelligence (OSINT), selecting the right operating system is a foundational decision that impacts both your anonymity and your tooling capabilities. This guide compares Kali Linux (with VPN) and Tails OS (with Tor) to help you choose the best environment based on your investigative goals.

docs.title: 🧠 Summary
docs.text: Feature Tails OS Kali Linux + VPN Network Routing 100% via Tor VPN-based Anonymity High (default) Medium (VPN-dependent) Tool Availability Limited (extendable) Extensive (default) Performance Slower (Tor overhead) Faster Forensic Traces None (amnesic) Present unless manually mitigated Use Case Sensitive, anonymous ops Tool-heavy, resource-intensive ops Persistence Optional & encrypted Native with encryption recommended Convenience Requires live boot Installable or virtualized

docs.title: 🛡️ When to Use Tails OS
docs.text: Tails (The Amnesic Incognito Live System) is built for privacy and anonymity. It is a live operating system you can start from a USB stick or DVD, and it leaves no trace on the machine unless explicitly configured to do so.

docs.title: ✅ Use Tails if:
docs.text:
• You need maximum anonymity and zero traceability.
  • You are conducting sensitive research (e.g., political, whistleblower, activist, or journalist work).
  • You want a fresh, disposable environment every time you boot.
  • You require all traffic to be routed through Tor.

docs.title: 🟢 Pros
docs.text:
• Amnesic: leaves no traces on disk.
  • Built-in Tor routing for all traffic.
  • Strong default security configurations.
  • Ideal for short, secure browsing or intelligence gathering.

docs.title: 🔴 Cons
docs.text:
• Limited built-in tools (can be extended with encrypted persistence).
  • Slower due to Tor routing.
  • Requires live boot; not ideal for long-term sessions.
  • Persistence adds complexity and some OpSec risk.

docs.title: 🛠️ Key Actions with Tails
docs.text:
• Always verify Tor connectivity: visit check.torproject.org.
  • Configure encrypted persistence only if necessary.
  • Avoid logging into personal accounts or reusing identities.

docs.title: 🧰 When to Use Kali Linux (with VPN)
docs.text: Kali Linux is a full-featured Linux distribution focused on penetration testing and security auditing, making it a powerful option for more tool-heavy OSINT work.

docs.title: ✅ Use Kali if:
docs.text:
• You need access to a wide range of OSINT tools like theHarvester, Maltego, GHunt, Sherlock, etc.
  • You are dealing with large datasets, scripting, or automation.
  • The site or target you’re investigating blocks Tor.
  • You need persistent storage, better performance, or virtualization.

docs.title: 🟢 Pros
docs.text:
• Preloaded with hundreds of security and OSINT tools.
  • Supports scripting, automation, and Python environments.
  • Virtualization-friendly for snapshots, isolated environments.
  • Better suited for intensive or long-term investigations.

docs.title: 🔴 Cons
docs.text:
• Not anonymous by default — requires VPN configuration.
  • Leaves traces on disk unless precautions are taken.
  • OpSec is entirely your responsibility (DNS leaks, kill switches, firewall rules, etc.).
  • VPN trust is critical — a bad provider defeats the purpose.

docs.title: 🔐 Key Actions with Kali
docs.text:
• Use a reputable no-logs VPN (e.g., Mullvad, ProtonVPN, NordVPN).
  • Always enable Kill Switch and check for DNS leaks.
  • Configure browser hygiene and isolate environments.
  • Consider running Kali in a VM with snapshots for rollback.

docs.title: 🔄 Decision Flow: Tails vs Kali for OSINT
docs.text:
Use this logic tree to decide which platform fits your operation:

  1. Do you need high anonymity and no traces? → Use Tails OS.

  2. Are you working with tools/scripts that require heavy system access or storage? → Use Kali Linux.

  3. Is Tor blocked by your target websites? → Use Kali + VPN.

  4. Is this a short, sensitive, disposable session? → Use Tails OS.

  5. Do you need a reproducible, scriptable environment? → Use Kali Linux (preferably in a VM with snapshots).

docs.title: 🔐 General OSINT Best Practices (Applies to Both)
docs.text:
• Threat Modeling: Define your adversary and threat level before starting.
  • Environment Isolation: Never mix personal and OSINT activities.
  • Burner Accounts: Always use aliases and dedicated accounts.
  • Browser Hygiene: Disable WebRTC, geolocation, and fingerprinting.
  • Documentation: Log everything — tools used, findings, search terms.
  • Legal & Ethical Compliance: Know the laws in your jurisdiction.
  • Assume Compromise: Treat your environment as compromised at all times.

docs.title: 📷 Reference Chart
docs.text: You can use the following image as a quick decision-making guide:

docs.title: 📎 Related Topics to Explore Next
docs.text:
• Installing Kali Linux in a Virtual Machine
  • Using Tails with Encrypted Persistence
  • Firefox Browser Privacy Hardening for OSINT
  • Setting Up a Secure VPN with Kill Switch in Kali
  • Installing Core OSINT Tools: Sherlock, GHunt, Amass

By understanding your threat model and technical needs, you can choose the right platform — Kali for power and tools, Tails for stealth and privacy.

Let your environment match your mission.

docs.title: 📚 Google Dorking for OSINT
docs.text: Google Dorking (also known as Google hacking) refers to using advanced search operators in Google to find specific, often hidden, pieces of information. It's a powerful and beginner-friendly OSINT technique used by cybersecurity professionals, journalists, and investigators.

docs.title: 🔍 What Is Google Dorking?
docs.text:
Google Dorking leverages the way Google indexes web content. By combining search terms with advanced operators, you can:

  • Discover publicly exposed files
  • Search within a specific domain
  • Find login portals
  • Identify vulnerable pages or misconfigurations
  • Locate public documents, images, or directories

⚠️ Ethical Reminder: Use Google Dorking responsibly. Only access information that is publicly available and not protected by authentication or privacy settings.

docs.title: 🧠 Example Use Case: Find Only Face Images of a Person
docs.text: This trick lets you refine Google Images to only show face-type images:

docs.title: Step-by-step:
docs.text:
1. Search the name using quotes for accuracy: "Elon Musk"

  2. Click on the 'Images' tab on Google.

  3. Click on: Tools → Type → Clipart

  4. In the URL, find this parameter: tbs=itp:clipart

  5. Replace itp:clipart with itp:face

  6. Press Enter.

docs.title: ✅ Result:
docs.text: Only face images of the target (e.g., Elon Musk) will be displayed.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
• Original: https://www.google.com/search?q="Elon+Musk"&...&tbs=itp:clipart

  • Modified: https://www.google.com/search?q="Elon+Musk"&...&tbs=itp:face

docs.title: 🛠️ Core Google Dork Operators
docs.text: Use Case Operator Example Search within a specific domain site: site:nytimes.com cybersecurity Search multiple domains OR "John Doe" site:facebook.com OR site:twitter.com Find specific file types filetype: filetype:pdf machine learning Keywords in page title intitle: intitle:"data privacy" All keywords in title allintitle: allintitle:"cybersecurity law" Keywords in page text intext: intext:"cyber threat" All keywords in text allintext: allintext:"malware statistics 2024" Keywords in URL inurl: inurl:"login" All keywords in URL allinurl: allinurl:"admin login panel" Number ranges numrange: numrange:2010-2020 Filter by date before: / after: filetype:pdf before:2020-01-01 after:2018-01-01 Language-specific results lang: site:gov.uk lang:en cybersecurity Wildcard keyword * "password * leak" Related websites related: related:bbc.com

docs.title: 1. Search for Exposed Files in Open Directories
docs.text:
intitle:"index of" "cisco" (pdf | doc | ppt)

Finds public folders listing Cisco-related documents.

docs.title: 2. Locate Documents on Misconfigured File Servers
docs.text:
inurl:"/files/" "cisco" filetype:pdf

Targets URLs with /files/, a common folder on unsecured servers.

docs.title: 3. Discover Documents in Backup Folders
docs.text:
inurl:backup "cisco" filetype:pdf

Identifies documents stored in backup folders—often overlooked during security audits.

docs.title: 4. Target Government or Organization Sites
docs.text:
site:.gov "cisco" filetype:pdf

Refines results to government domains. You can change .gov to .edu, .org, or country-specific domains like .fr, .de.

docs.title: 5.  Multi-parameter search query 1
docs.text:
("Spiderfoot") (intext:tutorial OR intext:"cheat sheet") (filetype:pdf OR filetype:ppt OR filetype:pptx)

Each group is in parentheses for clarity.Google treats whitespace as AND by default.

docs.title: 6.  Multi-parameter search query(2)
docs.text:
"Google Dork" site:github.com (sheet OR list OR query OR advanced OR osint) after:2021-01-01

OR — any of these related keywords

docs.title: 🎯 Practical Tips for Effective Dorking
docs.text:
• Use quotes for exact phrases: "john smith" instead of john smith
  • Combine operators for precise results: text site:linkedin.com "@gmail.com" "CTO"
  • Wildcard * helps to guess unknown terms: text "CEO of * Corporation"
  • Use numrange: to filter by years or values: text cyberattack statistics numrange:2010-2023

docs.title: ⚖️ Legal and Ethical Considerations
docs.text:
Google Dorking uses public search data indexed by Google. However:

  • Do not access pages protected by login or authorization.
  • Do not attempt to exploit vulnerabilities.
  • Use this technique for ethical research, journalism, education, or organizational security testing with permission.

docs.title: ✅ Summary
docs.text: Google Dorking is an essential OSINT skill that transforms basic search into a precision reconnaissance tool. By mastering search operators and refining queries, you can uncover valuable data hiding in plain sight.

docs.title: 📎 Suggested Next Steps
docs.text:
• Practice with safe searches like: text site:gov.uk "cybersecurity" intitle:"index of" filetype:pdf
  • Combine this with tools like SpiderFoot, theHarvester, or Recon-ng for automated data extraction.
  • Add browser extensions like Shodan Plugin to enhance in-browser reconnaissance.

🕵️‍♂️ Google Dorks Cheat Sheet for Hidden Paths & Exposed Files

📋 Table adapted from this GitHub repository. Original author unknown. All credit to the creator.

Google Dork What It Finds / Does inurl:web.config Finds exposed ASP.NET configuration files. May contain DB connection strings, secrets. intitle:"index of" "web.config" Searches for open directory listings containing web.config. inurl:.htaccess Finds exposed .htaccess files used by Apache (can reveal rules, paths, restrictions). inurl:.htpasswd Looks for Apache password files (used with .htaccess). May reveal hashed passwords. inurl:.env Exposes .env files—used in Laravel, Node.js, etc. Often includes API keys, DB creds. ext:bak OR ext:old OR ext:backup inurl:admin Finds backup/old files in admin directories (may contain original code/configs). intitle:"index of" ".git" Shows exposed .git repositories—can leak full project source code. intitle:"index of" ".svn" Finds exposed Subversion (SVN) version control directories. filetype:sql "insert into" OR "create table" Searches for SQL database dumps, usually from MySQL or PostgreSQL. filetype:json "mongo" OR "password" Finds JSON files with MongoDB configs or other sensitive credentials. intitle:"index of" "error_log" Finds open error log files (can contain paths, errors, user info). intitle:"phpinfo()" "PHP Version" Locates PHP info pages — these expose server config, installed extensions. intitle:"index of" (config|backup|admin|database) Finds open directories with config/backup/admin/database files. inurl:wp-content/debug.log Finds exposed debug logs in WordPress installs — may include stack traces, errors.

docs.title: Sheet List from the web :
docs.text: - - hackersonlineclub.com/google-hacking - www.boxpiper.com/posts/google-dork-list - www.boxpiper.com/posts/top-35-google-dorks-list

docs.title: 🐱‍💻 Kali Linux Virtual Machine Setup for OSINT (VirtualBox Guide)
docs.text: This guide walks you through the full process of setting up a Kali Linux virtual machine using VirtualBox on Windows 11, with specific configurations tailored for Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) investigations.

docs.title: 🛠️ Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, ensure the following:

  • Host OS: Windows, IOS,Linux
  • RAM: At least 8 GB total on your host machine (to allocate 4 GB+ to Kali)
  • Disk Space: At least 30 GB free

docs.title: 1. 🧰 Install VirtualBox
docs.text:
1. Download VirtualBox for Windows: 👉 https://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/Downloads

  2. Install VirtualBox and optionally download and install the VirtualBox Extension Pack for improved USB, network, and clipboard integration.

docs.title: 2. 📥 Download Kali Linux ISO
docs.text:
1. Go to: 👉 https://www.kali.org/get-kali/#kali-platforms

  2. Download the Kali Linux Installer (64-bit) ISO.

docs.title: 3. 📦 Create a Kali Linux VM
docs.text:
1. Open VirtualBox and click New:
  2. Name: Kali OSINT
  3. Type: Linux

  4. Version: Debian (64-bit)

  5. Set RAM:

  6. Minimum: 4096 MB (4 GB)

  7. Recommended: 6144 MB or more

  8. Create a virtual hard disk:

  9. Format: VDI (VirtualBox Disk Image)
  10. Storage: Dynamically allocated

  11. Size: At least 20 GB

  12. Adjust advanced settings:

  13. System → Processor: Allocate at least 2 CPUs
  14. Display → Video Memory: Set to 128 MB

  15. General → Advanced:

    • Shared Clipboard: Bidirectional
    • Drag and Drop: Bidirectional

  16. Mount the Kali ISO:

  17. Go to Settings → Storage
  18. Click the empty optical drive under Controller: IDE
  19. Click the disk icon → Choose a disk file → Select the Kali ISO

docs.title: 4. 🏗️ Install Kali Linux Inside the VM
docs.text:
1. Start the VM → Select Graphical Install

  2. Follow setup prompts:

  3. Language, Region, Keyboard: Choose based on your preference
  4. Hostname: kali-osint
  5. Domain: Leave blank
  6. Create a non-root user (recommended for security)

  7. Partitioning:

    • Select: Guided – Use entire disk
    • Choose: All files in one partition
    • Confirm with: Yes to write changes to disk

  8. Let the installation complete

  9. ⚠️ Important: After install, remove the ISO from the virtual drive before rebooting.

docs.title: 5. 🔧 Post-Install Configuration
docs.text: After your first boot:

docs.title: Update system and install essential tools:
docs.text: sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y git curl

docs.title: 6. 🧰 Clone and Run the OSINT Setup Script
docs.text:
Set up your OSINT tool environment:

git clone https://github.com/alex2t/kali-osint-setup.git
cd kali-osint-setup
chmod +x setup_osint_tools.sh
./setup_osint_tools.sh

This script installs: - APT-based tools: theHarvester, SpiderFoot, Amass - Python-based tools: Holehe, Social Analyzer - GitHub repos: Sherlock, GHunt, and more

📁 All tools will be available under ~/osint-tools

docs.title: 7. 🔌 Install Guest Additions for Clipboard & Display Enhancements
Step-by-step:
docs.text:
A. In the VirtualBox window:

Devices → Insert Guest Additions CD image…

B. Inside Kali terminal, run:

sudo apt update && sudo apt install -y build-essential dkms linux-headers-$(uname -r) && \
sudo mkdir -p /media/cdrom && \
sudo mount /dev/cdrom /media/cdrom && \
sudo /media/cdrom/VBoxLinuxAdditions.run && \
echo "✅ Done. Now reboot: sudo reboot"

C. Reboot your VM:

sudo reboot

Clipboard sharing will now work both ways.

docs.title: 8. 🌐 Firefox Extensions (Optional but Recommended)
docs.text:
Install useful browser extensions automatically:

sudo mkdir -p /usr/lib/firefox/distribution/
sudo cp firefox-policies/policies.json /usr/lib/firefox/distribution/

Then restart Firefox. Extensions like uBlock Origin, Wappalyzer, NoScript will auto-install.

docs.title: 9. 📸 Take a Snapshot (Highly Recommended)
docs.text:
Once your setup is complete and tested:

  • Shut down the VM
  • In VirtualBox Manager → Right-click the VM → Take Snapshot
  • Name: Base OSINT Setup

docs.title: 10. 🧠 Recommended VirtualBox Settings
docs.text: Setting Value Notes RAM 4 GB min 6 GB+ preferred CPU Cores 2 min 3–4 cores ideal Video Memory 128 MB Max it out Storage 20 GB+ Use Dynamically Allocated (VDI)

docs.title: 🔐 Browser Choices:
docs.text:
• Firefox (Recommended)
  • LibreWolf (privacy-hardened)
  • Chromium + privacy extensions

docs.title: 🧩 Extensions to Install (Firefox Only)
docs.text: Extension Purpose Firefox Add-on Link uBlock Origin Blocks trackers and ads uBlock Origin User-Agent Switcher Spoofs browser/OS fingerprints User-Agent Switcher Cookie AutoDelete Deletes cookies automatically Cookie AutoDelete Wappalyzer Identifies web technologies Wappalyzer NoScript Blocks unwanted JS execution NoScript Dark Reader Applies dark mode for readability Dark Reader SingleFile Save entire web pages as single HTML file SingleFile Copytables Copy HTML tables easily Copytables Shodan Plugin Display IP/domain intel via Shodan Shodan

docs.title: 🧰 Free Online Tools Useful in OSINT
docs.text:
• 🔍 Google Hacking Database
  • 🔗 URLScan.io (Scan & analyze URLs)
  • 📎 VirusTotal (Scan files & URLs)
  • 📨 URLClean (Deobfuscate/redact URLs)
  • 📱 Phone Number Search (CZ)
  • 📚 PDF to PowerPoint Converter
  • 🌍 IntelX (search leaked content & OSINT)
  • 📸 Archive.today (Snapshot any web page)
  • 🕵️‍♀️ Whois Lookup
  • 📍 IP Info
  • 🧭 Censys
  • 🌐 Wayback Machine
  • 👁️ SpiderFoot (demo)

docs.title: ⚠️ Privacy Tweaks in Firefox:
docs.text:
• Disable WebRTC:
  • Visit about:config
  • Search: media.peerconnection.enabled

  • Set to false

  • Disable Geolocation:

  • Visit about:config
  • Search: geo.enabled

  • Set to false

  • Private Mode Settings:

  • Visit about:preferences#privacy
  • Set: Firefox will use custom settings for history

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: To avoid cross-contamination between investigations and prevent tracking.

docs.title: Options:
docs.text:
• New Firefox Profile: bash firefox-esr --ProfileManager Create one per investigation (e.g., target-a, target-b).

  • Firefox Containers:

  • Install: Firefox Multi-Account Containers

  • Use one container per investigation (e.g., Company-A, Threat-Actor-X)

  • Private Mode:

  • Use Ctrl + Shift + P for temporary isolation
Isolation Level Best Method Full New profile per case Medium Firefox containers Temporary Private window Max Stealth Clean VM/browser

docs.title: Step 1: Install NordVPN CLI
docs.text:
sh <(curl -sSf https://downloads.nordcdn.com/apps/linux/install.sh)
sudo groupadd nordvpn
sudo usermod -aG nordvpn $USER
sudo reboot

docs.title: Step 2: Log In
docs.text:
nordvpn login

A browser window will open for authentication.

docs.title: Step 3: Connect to a Server
docs.text:
nordvpn connect         # Auto connect
nordvpn connect us      # Connect to a US server

docs.title: Step 4: Privacy Hardening
docs.text:
nordvpn set killswitch on
nordvpn set cybersec on
nordvpn set technology OpenVPN
nordvpn set obfuscate on

docs.title: Step 5: Auto-Connect (Optional)
docs.text: nordvpn set autoconnect on

docs.title: 14. 💾 Export or Clone Your Kali OSINT VM
docs.text:
To reuse or share your VM:

  • Snapshot: Right-click → Take Snapshot
  • Export OVA: File → Export Appliance

🧠 Reminder: Always use separate profiles or containers for different OSINT investigations to avoid tracking, linkage, or error in attribution.

docs.title: 🔧 Resize Your Kali Linux Virtual Machine Disk
docs.text:
This guide will walk you through the process of resizing your Kali Linux VM disk on a Windows host. This is useful if your virtual machine is running out of disk space and you need to expand it without reinstalling.

You'll learn how to:

  1. Increase the size of the virtual hard disk using the VBoxManage command.
  2. Expand the disk partition inside Kali using GParted.

docs.title: 🧱 PART 1: Resize the Virtual Disk Using VBoxManage
docs.text: The VBoxManage tool allows you to modify VirtualBox VMs from the command line. We'll use it to resize your .vdi file (virtual disk image).

docs.title: ✅ Step 1: Shut Down the VM
docs.text: Make sure your Kali VM is completely powered off — not suspended or in a saved state.

docs.title: ✅ Step 2: Open Command Prompt as Administrator
docs.text:
• Press Win + S and type cmd
  • Right-click Command Prompt → choose Run as administrator

docs.title: ✅ Step 3: Navigate to the VirtualBox Directory
docs.text:
If VirtualBox is not already in your system PATH, run this:

cd "C:\Program Files\Oracle\VirtualBox"

docs.title: ✅ Step 4: Resize the .vdi Virtual Disk File
docs.text:
Use the following command, replacing the path and size with your own values:

VBoxManage modifyhd "C:\Users\YourName\VirtualBox VMs\Kali\Kali.vdi" --resize 30000
  • "..." = Path to your .vdi file
  • 30000 = New size in MB (e.g., 30 GB)

💡 How to find the .vdi path: - Open VirtualBox - Right-click your Kali VM → Settings → Storage - Click your disk under "Controller: SATA" - Look at the bottom for the full file path

If successful, you'll see the message:

0%...10%...20%...100%
Image resized successfully.

docs.title: 🧱 PART 2: Resize the Linux Partition Inside Kali
docs.text: After expanding the virtual disk, you must resize the Linux partition inside the OS to actually use the new space.

docs.title: ✅ Step 5: Start Your Kali VM
docs.text: Boot into Kali as usual.

docs.title: ✅ Step 6: Install GParted (Partition Editor)
docs.text:
Open a terminal and run:

sudo apt update
sudo apt install gparted

docs.title: ✅ Step 7: Launch GParted
docs.text:
In the terminal, type:

sudo gparted

This opens the graphical partition editor.

docs.title: ✅ Step 8: Resize the Main Partition
docs.text:
1. In GParted, locate your main partition (usually /dev/sda1)
  2. Right-click the partition → select Resize/Move
  3. Drag the slider to use all unallocated space
  4. Click Resize
  5. Then click the green checkmark (✓) to apply changes
  6. Wait for the operation to finish
  7. Close GParted and reboot the VM

docs.title: ✅ Step 9: Confirm the New Disk Size
docs.text:
After reboot, open a terminal and run:

df -h

You should now see increased space under /dev/sda1 — for example:

Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/sda1        30G   5G   25G  17% /

docs.title: 🧠 Additional Tips
docs.text:
• Always back up your VM before resizing to avoid accidental data loss.
  • If you're using Snapshots, delete or merge them before resizing, as VBoxManage modifyhd won’t work on a snapshot chain.
  • If you prefer a GUI alternative, you can clone the VDI and specify a larger size during the clone process.

docs.title: ✅ Summary
docs.text:
Task Tool Used Notes Resize virtual disk VBoxManage Command line on Windows Install partitioning tool GParted Installed via apt inside Kali Resize Linux file system partition GParted GUI Drag slider to expand space Confirm new space df -h command Should show increased size on /dev/sda1

With this guide, you can now confidently expand your Kali Linux VM's disk size — a crucial skill when working with large datasets in OSINT investigations.

docs.title: 📡 theHarvester — OSINT Tool for Domain Reconnaissance
docs.text: theHarvester is an open-source OSINT (Open-Source Intelligence) tool designed for gathering emails, subdomains, IPs, and URLs using passive techniques. It's often used during the initial stages of penetration testing or red teaming to build a profile of a target domain.

docs.title: 🛠️ What Can theHarvester Do?
docs.text:
• Collect data passively (no interaction with the target’s infrastructure)
  • Enumerate:
  • Subdomains
  • Emails
  • Hosts/IPs
  • Employee names
  • API endpoints
  • Sources include:
  • Search engines (Google, Bing, DuckDuckGo, Yahoo)
  • Public repositories (GitHub, Shodan, crt.sh, RAPIDNS)
  • DNS brute-forcing with wordlists
  • Output formats: JSON, XML, HTML

docs.title: ⚙️ Basic Syntax
docs.text:
theHarvester -d [domain] -b [source] [options]
  • -d: Target domain (e.g. example.com)
  • -b: Data source (e.g. google, bing, crtsh, all)
  • -l: Result limit
  • -f: Save results to a file
  • -w: Wordlist file for brute-force
  • -c: Enable DNS brute-force
  • -v: Verbose output
  • -q: Quiet mode (suppress warnings)
  • -n: DNS resolution
  • --screenshot: Capture screenshots of discovered subdomains

docs.title: 1. Basic DNS Brute-Force
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -c -w subdomains.txt

Performs brute-force against DNS using a wordlist.

docs.title: 2. Save Results to File (JSON/XML)
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -c -w subdomains.txt -f result_output

Exports results for later review.

docs.title: 3. Subdomain Screenshots
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -c -w subdomains.txt --screenshot screenshots/

Visual capture of exposed interfaces.

docs.title: 4. Limit Scan Results
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -l 50 -c -w subdomains.txt

Quick scan with up to 50 results.

docs.title: 5. Multi-Source Scan
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -b all -c -w subdomains.txt -q

Pulls from all supported sources.

docs.title: 6. Verbose Output
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -v -c -w subdomains.txt

In-depth output during scan.

docs.title: 7. Brute + DNS Lookup
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -c -n -w subdomains.txt

Combines brute-forcing with DNS resolution.

docs.title: 8. Custom DNS Resolvers
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -r resolvers.txt -c -w subdomains.txt

Useful for avoiding DNS filtering.

docs.title: 9. Screenshots + Output
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com --screenshot screenshots/ -c -w subdomains.txt -f full_results

Complete visual and structured data dump.

docs.title: 10. Aggressive Enumeration
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -l 1000 -c -w subdomains.txt

Deep dive for high-value domains.

docs.title: 11. API Endpoint Scan
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -a -w endpoints.txt

Finds undocumented APIs.

docs.title: 12. API + Brute Force
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -a -c -w endpoints.txt

Comprehensive endpoint enumeration.

docs.title: 13. RAPIDNS Source
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -b rapiddns -c -w subdomains.txt

Great for passive DNS visibility.

docs.title: 14. Yahoo Source + Save
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -b yahoo -c -w subdomains.txt -f yahoo_report

Useful fallback when Google limits are reached.

docs.title: 15. CRT.sh + Screenshots
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -b crtsh -c -w subdomains.txt --screenshot screenshots/

Enumerates cert transparency logs.

docs.title: 16. Offset Start
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -S 100 -l 200 -c -w subdomains.txt

Skips first 100, fetches next 200 results.

docs.title: 17. Quiet Mode
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -b all -c -w subdomains.txt -q

Suppresses warnings — useful for automation.

docs.title: 18. Alternate Wordlist
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -c -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/namelist.txt

Use extensive or customized wordlists.

docs.title: 19. DuckDuckGo Source
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -b duckduckgo -c -w subdomains.txt

docs.title: 20. Passive Only (No DNS)
docs.text:
theHarvester -d example.com -w subdomains.txt

Avoids triggering alerts.

docs.title: 21. Subdomain Takeover Check
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -c -w subdomains.txt -t

docs.title: 22. Virtual Host Enumeration
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -n -v -c -w subdomains.txt

docs.title: 23. Short Scan with Report
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -l 25 -f short_scan -c -w subdomains.txt

docs.title: 24. Combine RAPIDNS + SiteDossier
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -b rapiddns,sitedossier -c -w subdomains.txt

docs.title: 25. Full API Scan + Output
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -a -w endpoints.txt -f apiscan_report

docs.title: 26. Internal Environment
docs.text: theHarvester -d test.internal -c -w internal_subs.txt -f testenv_report

docs.title: 27. GitHub Code Search
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -b github-code -c -w subdomains.txt

docs.title: 28. CRT.sh + RAPIDNS
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com -b crtsh,rapiddns -c -w subdomains.txt

docs.title: 29. Quiet Screenshot Run
docs.text: theHarvester -d example.com --screenshot out/ -c -w subdomains.txt -q

docs.title: 30. Batch Multiple Domains
docs.text:
for domain in domain1.com domain2.com; do
  theHarvester -d $domain -b all -c -w subdomains.txt -q -f $domain;
done

docs.title: 🧠 Pro Tips
docs.text:
• Use curated wordlists like SecLists: bash /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/
  • For stealth, combine -q and -n
  • Automate and log using -f for structured output
  • Ideal for pre-engagement reconnaissance

docs.title: ⚖️ Legal Disclaimer
docs.text: Always obtain proper authorization before scanning any domain. Unauthorized reconnaissance may violate ethical, legal, or organizational rules.
